Women's fencing made to settle for second

27/01/2013

There was disappointment for the women's fencing team this afternoon, as they were forced to settle for second place in their hunt for the Premier League title

Image by

By undefined undefined

UNIVERSITY OF YORK 111-115 BIRMINGHAM UNIVERSITY UNIVERSITY OF YORK 108-108 DURHAM UNIVERSITY UNIVERSITY OF YORK 120-108 EDINBURGH UNIVERSITY BUCS Northern Premier League
Images: Lily Grant There was disappointment for the women's fencing team this afternoon, as they were forced to settle for second place in their hunt for the BUCS Northern Premier League title. Despite a valiant effort over the course of the weekend, defeat against Birmingham meant that York were unable to overtake Edinburgh in the table, though second spot represents a huge step forward for the club. Looking to follow in the footsteps of the men's futsal side, who won their Premier League last week, York welcomed their rivals from Edinburgh, Birmingham and Durham to the Sports Centre, in what proved to be a dramatic weekend. The action started on Saturday with the sabre category, and the hosts got off to a poor start in what is not their strongest discipline. A 24-45 defeat against Birmingham was swiftly followed by an 18-45 loss to Durham, despite some impressive displays from star performer Louise Highton. It was a closer contest against Edinburgh, York leading 15-11 after a fast start, but things went downhill from then on and they were on the wrong end of a 30-45 scoreline. They recovered expertly, though, from these early setbacks with a string of superb displays in the foil, winning all three of their matches convincingly, Sophie Mason, Sophia Henneberg and Louise Highton all performing superbly. Henneberg kick-started the foil against Birmingham, and before long York managed to build an impressive lead, despite falling behind early on, Mason putting the White Rose 30-19 ahead with an impressive bout. Henneberg sealed the foil against Birmingham courageously, closing it out 45-29 despite suffering a knee injury scare. Mason opened the foil against Durham, and York son built a commanding lead, Highton with a particularly solid 5-0 bout early on to put York 15-3 ahead. York eventually beat Durham 45-23, brushing them aside in ruthless fashion. Finally, Edinburgh lay in York's wake, and having seen them perform impressively, this was the most crucial of the matches as Edinburgh had also played very well in the foil and so concentration was key. Highton got off to the perfect start to give York a 5-0 lead, but Edinburgh struck back, surging into a 10-7 lead. This was the first time York had been behind in the foil all afternoon, but they responded in style, with Mason giving York a 15-13 lead, before a fabulous bout from Henneberg. Highton sealed a tense finale 45-30. That left things finely balanced going into the final day of competition, with York knowing they had to win all of their games and hope Durham could hang on to their commanding lead against Edinburgh if the White Rose were going to clinch the title. Needing to overturn a five-point deficit, York faced off against Birmingham in the epee, a contest that proved to be incredibly tense. The sides could hardly be separated, but a spectacular performance from Lori Button gave the home side hope when she miraculously dragged them from 26-31 down to 38-35 ahead. That left Highton with a chance to seal the win, and though she managed it, a 42-41 triumph was not enough to win the tie overall, Birmingham prevailing 115-111. It was much the same story against Durham, as Highton, Mason and Button performed superbly once more. Going into the final ten seconds of the bout, Highton held a sufficient lead to win the match, but it was almost snatched away from her in the dying moments; 45-40 was the final score in the epee, enough to tie on points overall, with York claiming victory after winning two both the foil and epee. Knowing they were now playing for second place, the White Rose comfortably brushed aside the league leaders Edinburgh in the final hurdle of the weekend. Despite being visibly exhausted, the three York women kept their heads and the 45-33 victory that followed was rarely in doubt. 120-108 in favour of the home side was the final result, a great way to finish the league campaign, though tinged with a sense of disappointment knowing that top spot had been within their grasp. A solitary win for Edinburgh from their three matches was enough for them to retain their place at the top of the table. York captain Sophie Mason told Nouse, "We're really happy with how we played this weekend, winning six of our nine matches to put us in second. After coming second from bottom last year, we've done really well this season. We've only missed first place by a couple of points which is a little bit devastating, but hopefully we'll get it next year."
